Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: The school reports that the child was caught bullying a classmate, and the father needs to respond
Expectation2: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation2: Before starting structural work, the carpenter needs to inspect and maintain tools and equipment to ensure safety and efficiency
Story: I was tightening the last bolt on my toolbox when my phone buzzed. The school’s number flashed on the screen, and my heart sank. The principal’s voice was stern—my son had been caught bullying a classmate. They needed me to come in, to talk, to show I cared and would help set things right. I glanced at the half-assembled beams and the crew waiting for my inspection. As the lead carpenter, it was my job to check every tool, every harness, to make sure no one got hurt. If I left now, I’d be letting my team down, risking their safety and the project’s schedule. But if I stayed, I’d be the father who wasn’t there when his child needed guidance most. The weight of both responsibilities pressed on me, each demanding my presence, each unforgiving if I failed. My hands trembled, torn between the job that put food on our table and the son who needed me to show him right from wrong.
